title.value: Circulating IL-17F, but not IL-17A, is elevated in severe COVID-19 and leads to an ERK1/2 and p38 MAPK-dependent increase in ICAM-1 cell surface expression and neutrophil adhesion on endothelial cells
title.justification: The title is directly stated at the beginning of the paper and fully encapsulates the primary subject and findings of the research.
title.quote: Circulating IL-17F, but not IL-17A, is elevated in severe COVID-19 and leads to an ERK1/2 and p38 MAPK-dependent increase in ICAM-1 cell surface expression and neutrophil adhesion on endothelial cells.

extractions.description: The paper investigates the role of IL-17 cytokines, particularly IL-17F, in the severity of COVID-19 and their effect on neutrophil adhesion and ICAM-1 expression in endothelial cells, mediated through MAPK pathways.

type.justification: The paper involves experimental studies to measure cytokine levels and their effects on cell adhesion, as well as validation with independent cohorts.
type.quote: We measured the in vitro impact of IL-17F on intercellular adhesion molecule 1 (ICAM-1) cell surface expression and neutrophil adhesion on endothelial cells in culture.

name.justification: The study focuses on cytokines and immune responses in the context of COVID-19 severity.
name.quote: Severe COVID-19 is associated with neutrophilic inflammation and immunothrombosis.

name.justification: The research involves molecular pathways like MAPK and the expression of proteins such as ICAM-1 on cells.
name.quote: The contribution of two Mitogen Activated Protein Kinase (MAPK) pathways was determined using small molecule inhibitors PD184352 and BIRB0796.

name.justification: COVID-19 is caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, and the paper investigates immunological responses to this virus.
name.quote: COVID-19 is an infectious disease attributable to the SARS-CoV-2 virus.

name.justification: The BQC19 dataset was used for the primary analysis of the cytokine levels in COVID-19 patients.
name.quote: We investigated the association between COVID-19 and circulating plasma levels of IL-17 cytokine family members in participants to the Biobanque québécoise de la COVID-19 (BQC19), a prospective observational cohort.

referenced_paper_title.value: The Biobanque qué bé coise de la COVID-19 (BQC19)-A cohort to prospectively study the clinical and biological determinants of COVID-19 clinical trajectories
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference to BQC19 in the paper matches the described study and dataset usage.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The Biobanque qué bé coise de la COVID-19 (BQC19)-A cohort to prospectively study the clinical and biological determinants of COVID-19 clinical trajectories.

name.justification: Another cohort dataset from Western University was used to validate findings from the BQC19.
name.quote: Validation was carried out in data obtained from Western University (London, Ontario) as previously reported.

referenced_paper_title.value: COVID-19 plasma proteome reveals novel temporal and cell-specific signatures for disease severity and high-precision disease management
referenced_paper_title.justification: This reference matches the described cohort and its use for validation in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: COVID-19 plasma proteome reveals novel temporal and cell-specific signatures for disease severity and high-precision disease management.

name.justification: The paper mentions using Fiji/ImageJ software for imaging analysis.
name.quote: All of the analysis of the images was done using Fiji/ImageJ software for Microsoft Windows.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Fiji/ImageJ is a widely recognized software with a comprehensive user guide rather than a specific paper reference.
referenced_paper_title.quote: All of the analysis of the images was done using Fiji/ImageJ software for Microsoft Windows.
